--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Mitchell's idea sounds good as well for the
> TTT-memory domain.  But 
> I guess you still need a stopping criterion in case
> the network 
> never says it's ready.  Also, the complexity of
> representing what it 
> means to be "ready" may be almost as difficult to
> discover as the 
> solution itself, in which case its value would be
> questionable.  But 
> I don't know that to be the case so it's definitely
> worth trying.

Yes, you do need a backup stopping criteria in case
the network doesn't acheive "ready".  Those would be
low fitness networks, but there will be many of them. 
What I do is count the internal cycles, and I enforce
a maximum, usually 16.  Also, I include a small
penalty for excessive cycling in the fitness function,
to favor those nets that come to a decision with few
cycles.  If a net reaches the limit of 16 cycles I
give it a very low fitness score.
